title: Jurgen Klopp hails Alisson for saving Liverpool in moment where he didn't even touch the ball
text:

Jurgen Klopp has praised Liverpool goalkeeper Alisson for saving his team against Tottenham despite not touching the ball.

The Reds came from behind to beat Spurs at Anfield on Sunday and maintain their unbeaten run in the Premier League this season.

However a pivotal moment in the match saw Son Heung-Min crash a golden opportunity off the crossbar with the score at 1-0, having rounded Alisson to leave the goal gaping at his mercy.

But Klopp was adamant it was the work of his goalkeeper which should be lauded, and not Son's miss.

“They had a big chance in the second half, and I told the boys at half-time the only problem in this game so far is the result," Klopp said.

(Image: Getty Images)

“Their chance was just a long kick, not even a pass. Dejan (Lovren) misjudged it, thinks he can let it bounce and Son is away and Ali made a really special save.

“He didn’t touch the ball but he was so big in that moment he made life really difficult for Son.”

An early goal from Harry Kane had put the visitors in front, after Son's deflected shot had hit the post via Lovren, before his teammate headed in the rebound.

Liverpool peppered the Spurs goalmouth, and eventually got their reward not long after Son's squandered opportunity.

(Image: Getty Images)

Fabinho picked out Jordan Henderson with a ball into the box - despite the best efforts of Danny Rose to stop its progress - before the Reds captain struck a half-volley into the far corner.

The onslaught continued into the Kop end as Liverpool went in search of a winner, and were handed the chance when Serge Aurier clumsily brought down Sadio Mane in the box.

Referee Anthony Taylor had no hesitation in pointing to the spot, allowing Mohamed Salah to step up and fire home the winner.

Liverpool restored their six-point lead over rivals Man City, but Klopp was keen to play down any early title talk.

“We now have 28 points, but you only have to think what would have happened if we lost today, what the questions would have been," Klopp added.

“We know exactly what we have to do. We have to focus on all the games, next one Arsenal , then Aston Villa, then Genk, then Manchester City . There is a lot to come but so far, so good.”
description: The goalkeeper made just his fourth appearance of the season against Tottenham and was involved in a crucial moment
